Name: Is there a distinct category of dual for verbal agreement with a dual subject?
Is non-agreement in number between the nominal subject and verbal predicate possible?
Can finite verbs agree in number with the nominal object?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in case?
Are there cases that do not show agreement in terms of case?
Can adpositions be used to mark core verbal arguments?
Can adpositions be used to mark non-core/oblique verbal arguments?
Example: A labda a fa mögött van;DEF ball DEF tree behind be.PRS.3SG;The ball is behind the tree;

Name: Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (S/A) marking?
Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (P) marking?
Do characteristics of object referent (topicality, animacy, definiteness) influence object marking?
Does object marking correlate with aspectuality?
Does the marking of the object depend on the verb conjugation form?
Is there differential subject marking?
Can S and A be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Example: A kutya meg-harap-ta a fiú-t és el-fut-ott;DEF dog PRV-bite-PST.OC DEF boy-ACC and PRV-run-PST.3SG;The dog bit the boy and run away;

Name: Can S and P be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Is there a grammatical device for habituality?
Is there a grammatical device for frequentative?
Is there a grammatical device for progressivity?
Is it common to use a verb in the present tense for future time reference?
Example: Holnap el-megy-ek a bolt-ba;tomorrow PRV-go-PRS.1SG DEF shop-ILL; Tomorrow I will go to the shop;

Name: Is there a grammatical device for immediate future?
Is there a grammatical device for pluperfect?
Can aspect be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Can tense be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Is there grammatical marking of mirativity?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of desire or wish?
Is there morphological marking for irrealis (e.g. hypothetical state of affairs)?
Example: El-men-né-k a bolt-ba, ha nem es-ne az eső;PRV-go-COND-1SG DEF shop-ILL if NEG fall-COND.3SG DEF rain;I would go to the shop, if it did not rain;

Name: Are verbs marked in a specific mood in counterfactual conditional clauses?
Example: Ha reggeliz-te-m vol-na, nem len-né-k most éhes;If eat.breakfast-PST-1SG be.PST-COND NEG be.PRS-COND-1SG now hungry;If I would have eaten breakfast, I would not be hungry now;

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic necessity?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of epistemic possibility?
Example: Egy nap-on még meg-talál-hat-juk őt;one day-SPRESS yet PRV-find-DER-1PL.OC 3SG-ACC;We may find him on one day;|A dolog meg-old-ód-hat holnap-ra;DEF thing PRV-solve-REFL-DER.PRS.3SG tomorrow-SUBL;The thing may be solved by tomorrow;
Comment: Epistemic possibility can be encoded on the verb with the derivational suffix -hat/-het.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic possibility?
Comment: The suffix -hat/-het may also encode permission.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 3Sg?
Example: Jöj-j-ön el!;come-IMP-3SG PRV;Let her/him come!;|Beszél-j-en-ek!;talk-IMP-3-PL; Let them talk!;

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 1Sg?
Example: Az-t mond-ta, hogy men-j-ek el;that-ACC say-PST.3SG.OC that go-IMP-1SG PRV;S/he said to me to go away;

Name: Is it common to use the imperative/jussive in complement clauses introduced by predicates expressing wish/desire/will?
Example: Az-t akar-ja, hogy énekel-j-ek;that-ACC want-PRS.3SG.OC that sing-IMP-1SG;S/he wants me to sing;

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of apprehension?
Is there reflexive conjugation?
Are there syntactically ditransitive verbs?
Can non-singular 2nd and 3rd person have the same person/number marking or morphosyntactic treatment?
Can an impersonal (or passive) form be used instead of a finite plural form with an overt subject expression?
Can third person plural verb forms be used for impersonal reference?
Example: Itt beszél-nek magyar-ul;here speak-PRS.3PL Hungarian-ESS;Hungarian is spoken here / One can speak Hungarian here;

Name: Can second person singular verb forms be used in generic meaning?
Example: Itt nem sátor-oz-hat-sz;here NEG tent-VBZ-POT-PRS.2SG;You may not camp here / One may not camp here;

Name: Are clauses with only infinitive predicates possible?
Can verbs in purposive subordinate clauses be in bare infinitive form?
Example: Magyarország-ra megy-ek magyar-ul tanul-ni;Hungary-SUBL go-PRS.1SG Hungarian-ESS study-INF;I'm going to Hungary to learn Hungarian;

Name: Are there sentences without overt verbal arguments (e.g. weather verbs)?
Comment: Usually it is necessary to specify what is raining but when it becomes clear from the context it is enough to say esik 'raining'.

Name: Is copula needed for predicate nominals in the 3rd person form of the present tense?
Is a copula needed for predicate nominals in the past and/or future tense?
Example: Ő tanár volt;3SG teacher be.PST.3SG;S/he was a teacher;|Ő tanár lesz;3SG teacher be.FUT.3SG;S/he will be a teacher;

Name: Can locative adverbial phrases act as predicates without a copula?
Can the same coordinating conjunction be used for NPs, VPs, and clauses?
Example: Anna és Péter;;Anna and Péter;|Anna olvas és tanul;Anna read.PRS.3SG and study.PRS.3SG;Anna reads and studies;|Anna olvas és Péter tanul;Anna read.PRS.3SG and Péter study.PRS.3SG; Anna reads and Péter studies;

Name: Does existential negation have a separate operator?
Example: Nincs otthon kenyér;NEG home.LOC bread;There is no bread at home;
Comment: To compare, standard negation is expressed using "nem": Nem megyek haza (NEG go-PRS.1SG home) 'I do not go home'.

Name: Can standard negation be asymmetric in the present tense?
Can non-finite dependent clauses use the standard negation construction?
Example: Nem lát-va a kutyá-t, megbotl-ott;NEG see-PTCP DEF dog-ACC trip.over-PST.3SG; As he did not see the dog, he tripped over;|Nem lát-ta meg a kutyá-t és megbotl-ott;NEG see-PST.3SG PRV DEF dog and trip.over-PST.3SG;He did not see the dog and tripped over;

Name: Is there a special negator that combines with non-finite forms?
Are there special negative non-finite forms?
Is there an impersonal passive construction?
Are there nonfinite forms specialized on the relativization of particular core participants, e.g. subjects (S/A), direct objects (P), absolutive participants (S/P)?
Example: olvas-ó fiú; read-PTCP boy;a boy who is reading|olvas-ott könyv; read-PTCP book; a book that has been read;

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least all core participants (S/A/P) and possibly also some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials, instruments, etc.?
Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials or instruments, but cannot relativize all or some of the core participants, e.g. subjects?
Is there a specialized negative participial form, which cannot be analyzed as a specific participial marker + negation marker?
Is there a future participle?
Example: Olvas-andó könyv;read-PTCP book;a book that will be/has to be read;
Comment: The future participle also expresses necessity.

Name: Are there participles that can encode their subject by possessive suffixes?
Comment: Participles do not encode the subject, e.g. Az általam megcsinált munka / A megcsinált munkám.

Name: Can subject in at least some participial subordinate clauses be encoded in the same way as in independent clauses?
Example: Az Anna említ-ett-e könyv;DEF Anna mention-PTCP-POSS.3SG book;The book mentioned by Anna;
Comment: In independent clauses, the subject appears in the nominative form, e.g.: Anna említ-ette, hogy ez egy érdekes könyv (Anna mention-PST.3SG that this a interesting book) 'Anna mentioned that this is an interesting book',

Name: Are there participles that obligatorily agree with the nouns they modify in case and number (in all contexts)?
Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and action nominalizations?
Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and agentive nominalizations?
Example: ír-ó;write-PTCP;writer;|ír-ó fiú;write-PTCP boy;a boy who is writing;

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and converbs without any additional morphological material, such as case markers?
Is OV the neutral order in affirmative imperative clauses?
Example: Idd meg a teát!;drink.IMP.2SG.OC PRV DEF tea-ACC;Drink up the tea!;|Igyál teát!;drink.IMP.2SG tea-ACC;Drink tea!;

Name: Is it possible to place an object between the negative marker and the main verb in imperative constructions?
Example: Ne az-t a teá-t idd meg, hanem amaz-t!;NEG that-ACC DEF tea-ACC drink.IMP.2SG.OC PRV but that.one-ACC;Do not drink this tea, but that one!;|Ne a barát-ai-d-at felejt-sd el, hanem az ellenség-ei-d-et!;NEG DEF friend-PL-POSS.2SG-ACC forget-IMP.2SG.OC but DEF enemy-PL-POSS.2SG-ACC;Do not forget your friends but your enemies!;

Name: Are there preverbs?
Example: Ki-viszem a tányért;out-take-PRS.1SG DEF plate-ACC;I take the plate (out);

Name: Are there verbal prefixes?
Is there diminutive (hypocoristic) marking on verbs?
Comment: Diminutive marking is possible, but it is used only by some people when talking  to children, e.g. Mosikázd meg a kezecskéidet evés előtt (wash-DIM-IMP.2SG.OC PRV DEF hand-DIM-PL-POSS.2SG eating before) 'Wash your hands before eating'.

Name: Can modifiers of action nominalization in agent and patient roles both be marked like possessors?
Example: A fiú meg-mosás-a/meg-fürdetése;DEF boy PRV washing-POSS.3SG/PRV-bathing-POSS.3SG;the washing of the boy, the bathing of the boy;|a fiú szobája;DEF boy room-POSS.3SG;the boy's room;

Name: Can the modifier of action nominalization in patient role (e.g. "drinking of coffee") be marked like the direct object?
Do core adjectives agree with the subject noun in number in the predicative position?
Example: A kutyák okosak;DEF dog-PL smart-PL;Dogs are smart;

Name: Is it possible to form synthetic superlative?
Can adpositions have person/number marking?
Example: A fa mellett;DEF tree beside;beside the tree;|mellett-em;beside-POSS.1SG; beside me;|mellett-ünk;beside-POSS.1PL;beside us;

Name: Are there separate adpositions to express goal, source, and location (without there being syncretism)?
Example: A kutya a ház elé fut;DEF dog DEF house before.ILL run.PRS.3SG;The dog runs in front of the house;|A kutya a ház előtt van;DEF dog DEF house before.INE be.PRS.3SG;The dog is in front of the house;|A kutya a ház elől futott el;DEF dog DEF house before.ELA run-PST.3SG PRV;The dog ran from the front of the house;

Name: Is case compounding possible?
Are there case categories only found in pronouns?
Does the numeral modification of a noun have an effect on its case selection?
Is the singular form of the noun also used with numerals bigger than 1?
Example: egy ház;;one house;|két ház;;two houses;|száz ház;;hundred houses;

Name: Is there a genitive case that has an affix?
Is there a dative case used to express indirect object/receiver/goal (different from a local case)?
Example: A fiú a lánynak adta a könyvet;DEF boy DEF girl-DAT give-PST.3SG.OC DEF book-ACC;The boy gave the book to the girl;|A fiú be-ment a ház-ba/rá-ült az asztal-ra/oda-ment az ablak-hoz;DEF boy in-go-PST.3SG house-ILL/on-sit DEF table-SUBL/there-go-PST.3SG DEF window-ALL;The boy went in the house/sat on the table/went to the window;

Name: Is there a terminative case?
Example: Tatabányá-ig megy-ek;Tatabánya-TERM go-PRS.1SG;I travel till Tatabánya;

Name: Is there a separate case to indicate without what/who an action takes place / does not take place?
Example: Táskátlanul/ruhátlanul mentem az iskolába;bag-PRIV-ESS/clothes-PRIV-ESS go-PST.1SG DEF school-ILL;I went to school without a bag/without clothes;
Comment: However, it is more common to use the postposition nélkül 'without'.

Name: Is there a separate case to mark the motion along or by the referent of the noun (prolative)?
Is there a locative case that marks goal?
Is there a locative case that marks location?
Is there a locative case that marks source?
Is there case syncretism of goal and location marking?
Comment: There is syncretism in the spoken Hungarian: both the illativ and inessiv case may sound -ba/-be, e.g. könyvtárba megyek 'I am going to the library', olvasok a könyvtárba(n) 'I am reading in the library', where -n does not sound.

Name: Is there case syncretism of location and source marking?
Are there two sets of local cases?
Comment: There is a distinction between internal and external local cases, and there is also a third set used to express proximity.

Name: Is there a third set of local cases?
Is there a separate case for marking the means by which something is carried out (instrumental) and/or accompaniement (comitative)?
Is there a separate case for marking accompaniment, which is different from the instrumental?
Is there a separate case for marking the result of change (translative) and/or a state of being (essive)?
Example: Orvos-nak tanul-t / Orvos-sá vált;doctor-DAT study-PST.3SG / doctor-TRA become-PST.3SG;S/he studied to be a doctor / S/he became a doctor;

Name: Is there a separate case for marking the state of being (essive), which is different from the translative?
Example: Orvos-ként dolgoz-ik;doctor-ESS work-PRS.3SG;S/he works as a doctor;

Name: Is there a separate morphological marker for expressing equative meaning?
Is there an inflectional nominal marker for expressing benefactive or destinative semantics independent from the dative?
Is there in addition to the basic declension a declension different from a possessive declension?
Is it possible to use singular with paired body parts/clothing/accessories that accompany them?
Example: Mosd meg a kez-ed-et;wash PRV DEF hand-POSS.2SG-ACC;Wash your hands;

Name: Can the marking of the possessor in the attributive construction vary?
Example: Az ember-nek a barát-ja;DEF human-DAT friend-POSS.3SG;;|Az ember barát-ja;DEF human friend-POSS.3SG;friend of man;

Name: Can the possessor in the attributive construction be marked with the nominative?
Example: Az ember barát-ja;DEF human friend-POSS.3SG;friend of man;

Name: Is non-singular possession marked in the possessive declension?
Can 2Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Can 3Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Is there animacy distinction in independent interrogative pronouns?
When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for animates other than humans?
Comment: ki 'who' is sometimes used for animals but such usage does not follow the standards. However, such usage is possible in dialects.

Name: When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for inanimates?
Can a demonstrative stem be used in the function of a pronoun with 3rd person singular human referent?
Example: Mit keres ez itt?;what-ACC look.for.PRS.3SG this here;What does he look for here?;
Comment: Usage of a demonstrative pronoun for human referent tends to have a pejorative meaning.

Name: Is the order of possessive suffix and case suffix across the paradigm the same?
Is the order of number and case suffixes fixed across the paradigm the same?
Are there different words for mother’s brother and father’s brother?
Are there different words for younger and older relative for other relations than siblings?
Is there animacy distinction for both concepts 'new/young' and 'old'?
Example: régi film vs. öreg ember;;old movie vs. old man;|új ruha vs. fiatal férfi;;new dress vs. young man;

Name: Is there distinction for both 'warm' and 'cold' based on whether referring to weather or to temperature of objects?
Is there contrastive length of consonants?
Is there contrastive length of vowels?
Comment: Length may also influence the quality.

Name: Is there contrast between short and long unstressed vowels?
Is there contrast in duration of geminate consonants?
Are there more than two phonological quantities?
Are there extralong syllables?
Is the main foot structure trochaic?
Is there lexically distinctive word stress?
Is there morphologically conditioned stress?
Comment: It seems that secondary stressed derivational suffixes often contain a long vowel.

Name: Is there fixed primary stress?
Is there stress in heavy syllables?
Is there non-initial primary stress?
Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Is there velar vowel harmony?
Is there labial vowel harmony?
Are there rising diphthongs?
Comment:
There are a lot of rising diphtongs in Hungarian dialects, e.g.
Eastern and Palóc Hungarian
vout be.PST.3SG 'szeip 'nice'.

Name: Are there lowering diphthongs?
Is there qualitative contrast between subsets of short and long vowels?
Are there full vs. reduced vowels as contrastive subsets?
Is there front high rounded vowel ü [y]?
Is there front midhigh rounded vowel ö [ø]?
Is there back high unrounded vowel ï [ɯ]?
Is there back midhigh unrounded vowel ë [ɤ]?
Is there back low round vowel [ɒ]?
Is there contrast between low and mid front vowels (ä [æ] vs. e [e])?
Comment: There is ë in the major part of Hungarian dialect area, except North-Western subdialects, furthermore, there are rising diphtongs with ë, cf. Csángó and Old Palóc eën 'I'.

Name: Are there word-initial consonant clusters?
Comment: In loanwords and in descriptive/onomatopoeic words.

Name: Are there word-internal consonant clusters in syllable onset?
Are there consonant clusters in syllable coda?
Are there clusters of three or more consonants in a word between vowels?
Are there word-final clusters of three or more consonants?
Comment: Rare but possible.

Name: Are there palatalized dentals?
Comment: There are palatal (not palatalized) consonants.

Name: Are there palatalized labials and velars?
Is there palatal stop [c]?
Is there palatal nasal [ɲ]?
Is there palatal lateral [ʎ]?
Comment: [ʎ] can only be found in the central-Palóc subdialects and Eastern subdialects, it is absent from the standard and the other dialects areas. Most of today's speakers cannot differentiate between [j] and [ʎ].

Name: Is there phonemic velar nasal [ŋ]?
Is there dental affricate [t͡s]?
Is there non-alveolar affricate (e.g. [t͡ʃ], [͡cɕ])?
Is there a phonological contrast between [s] and postalveolar sibilant [ʃ]?
Are there voiced plosives [b, g, d]?
Is there glottal stop [ˀ]?
Is there phonological contrast between plain and labial velar consonants (e.g. [k] vs. [kʷ])?
Is there a constraint on word-initial r?
Is there laryngeal fricative [h]?
Is there voiced velar fricative [ɣ]?
Is there voiceless velar fricative [x]?
Is there voiced dental fricative [ð]?
Is there phonemic labio-velar approximant [w]?
Is there voiceless labiodental fricative [f]?
Is there radical qualitative consonant gradation?
Is there quantitative consonant gradation?
